questions.stem: Which PACE provision is most directly focused on excluding unreliable or oppressively obtained confessions?

options.text: PACE 1984 s.24
PACE 1984 s.58
PACE 1984 s.76
PACE 1984 s.40

questions.explanation: Section 76 is the confession-specific exclusion provision, focused on oppression and unreliability. Section 78 is broader fairness discretion covering evidence generally.

questions.stem: When might you rely on PACE s.78 rather than s.76?

options.text: When challenging a confession obtained by oppression
When challenging evidence on broader fairness grounds (not limited to confessions)
When challenging arrest necessity
When requesting a custody review

questions.explanation: Section 78 is a general discretion to exclude evidence where admission would adversely affect fairness. It can apply beyond confessions (e.g., procedural breaches affecting fairness).

questions.stem: Which is an example of 'testimonial' evidence?

options.text: A knife recovered from a bin
A witness statement describing what they saw
A fingerprint lifted from a surface
A CCTV recording of an incident

questions.explanation: Testimonial evidence is a person’s account (written or oral). Physical objects, fingerprints, and CCTV are generally real/digital evidence rather than testimonial.

questions.stem: Why is it risky for a client to speculate about evidence they have not seen in interview?

options.text: Speculation is always a criminal offence
Speculation can create inconsistencies that look like lies when evidence later emerges
Speculation forces the police to disclose their evidence
Speculation makes the interview inadmissible automatically

questions.explanation: Guessing details can trap the client into contradictions when objective evidence appears later. A safer approach is to avoid speculation and stick to what they genuinely know/remember.

references.cite: Interview best practice: avoid speculation (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: If an interview safeguard breach occurs (e.g., required AA absent), what is the most accurate impact statement?

options.text: The interview is automatically deleted and cannot be used
The breach may support an admissibility/fairness challenge depending on facts and severity
The breach has no relevance once the client is charged
The police must release the client immediately

questions.explanation: Safeguard breaches do not always make evidence inadmissible automatically, but they can be highly significant and may support applications to exclude evidence on fairness grounds.

questions.stem: Which phrase best describes 'oppression' in the context of confession challenges?

options.text: Any questioning by police
Improper pressure or conduct that may overwhelm the will of the suspect
A suspect refusing to answer questions
A routine caution being given

questions.explanation: Oppression refers to improper pressure or conduct. Whether something amounts to oppression depends on facts; document concerns contemporaneously and consider s.76/s.78 frameworks.

questions.stem: Which is the best example of 'digital evidence'?

options.text: A handwritten note found in a pocket
CCTV footage from a shop camera
A witness describing events
A pair of gloves

questions.explanation: Digital evidence includes recordings and electronic data (e.g., CCTV, phone messages, location data), which often require careful handling and can strongly affect strategy.

questions.stem: You receive disclosure that includes CCTV but you have not seen it. Which is the safest advice principle for interview?

options.text: Assume CCTV proves guilt; advise full admissions
Avoid speculating about what CCTV shows; ask for a description/summary and tailor strategy accordingly
Tell the client to guess what CCTV might show to sound convincing
Insist the police play the CCTV in the interview as a right in every case

questions.explanation: Without seeing the material, speculation is risky. Seek a clear summary of what it is said to show and consider whether a prepared statement or limited account is appropriate.
